name: Hveragerði
description: Hveragerði is a geothermally active town of approximately 2,700 residents located 45 kilometers east of Reykjavík in South Iceland, often called "The Hot Springs Capital of the World" and "Earthquake Town" due to its remarkable geological characteristics. Situated within the highly active geothermal field of the Hengill central volcano system, the town experiences very frequent seismic activity—usually minor tremors that residents have learned to live with, though occasionally more significant earthquakes occur. On May 29, 2008, a powerful magnitude 6.3 earthquake struck with its epicenter just 2 kilometers southeast of Hveragerði, causing substantial damage to buildings and infrastructure while fortunately resulting in no fatalities. The town's very existence and development are intimately tied to geothermal activity, with hot springs, steam vents, and bubbling mud pools dotting the landscape throughout the settlement and surrounding hillsides. This abundant natural heat revolutionized Icelandic horticulture when the first geothermally-heated greenhouse was established in Hveragerði in 1923, enabling year-round cultivation of vegetables and flowers despite Iceland's harsh Arctic winters. This innovation positioned Hveragerði as Iceland's horticultural capital, and today the town produces tomatoes, cucumbers, bell peppers, tropical fruits, and famously bananas in heated greenhouses, making it the world's northernmost banana-producing location. Visitors can tour operational greenhouses to witness tropical plants thriving in a sub-Arctic environment. The Geothermal Park (Hveragarður) in the town center provides an accessible introduction to Iceland's geothermal phenomena, featuring boardwalk paths winding among steaming fumaroles, colorful hot springs, and bubbling mud pots. Interpretive signs explain the geological processes creating these features and the town's history of harnessing geothermal energy. A traditional geothermal bakery demonstrates centuries-old techniques for baking bread underground using only natural earth heat. The Health Clinic (Heilsustofnun NLFÍ) offers comprehensive wellness programs utilizing the town's geothermal resources, including deep-heat mud baths, massages, therapeutic steam baths, two swimming pools, and multiple hot tubs, attracting visitors seeking relaxation and health treatments. Hveragerði serves as the gateway to Reykjadalur ("Steam Valley"), one of Iceland's most popular geothermal hiking destinations, located just 5 kilometers from town. The moderately challenging 3.5-kilometer trail leads to a naturally heated river where bathers can soak in warm water flowing through a scenic mountain valley. The town provides all essential services including hotels, guesthouses, restaurants, supermarkets, gas stations, and the excellent Sudurbudin bakery café. As a residential community rather than purely a tourist destination, Hveragerði offers authentic insight into how Icelanders have adapted to and benefited from living atop one of Earth's most geologically active zones.
